speaker: Chris Collins
vclaim: Chris Jacobs says he's never called Tramper.
date: stated on May 21, 2019 in a fundraising email:
title: There's no evidence that Chris Jacobs is ever Trumper.
text: Chris Collins responded to the news that the state of Sin Chris Jacobs, a fellow Republican, was planning to run for his seat in 2020, criticizing Jacobs on several fronts and repeating his claim that Jacobs was never Trumper. "With the radical left focus on resistance and obstruction, President Trump needs allies in Congress now more than ever," Collins wrote in an e-mail to collect donations on 21 May 2019. "Chris Jacobs may act like that kind of ally - but in fact, he's not one of those who will say and do anything to get elected for his next position." Collins of Clarence is facing federal charges of internal commerce and has been stripped of the functions of his committee by the Republican leadership in the House of Representatives. A trial is scheduled for early 2020. Collins did not say whether he would run in 2020, but he manipulated President Trump ' s strong support in the face of Jacob ' s announcement that he would seek a seat. Collins was one of the first congressmen to support Trump and appeared on national television several times in support of the President. Since Collins repeated several times his claim that Jacobs "was never Trumper," we wanted to know if that was true. According to the Democratic District of Jacobs, he voted for Trump and supported his agenda, but Jacobs did not flash his support during the 2016 campaign. At that time, Jacobs was a candidate for the New York Senate in the 60th District, where Democrats had a great advantage in registering and only 26 per cent of voters were registered Republicans. We contacted one of Collins' employees in search of evidence to support the claim, but for two days they didn't respond. Collins' e-mail fundraiser contains a passage from an interview in September 2016 with Jacobs on a government political television show tonight. In this, host Liz Benjamin asks Jacobs whether he supports Trump. - (Jacobs) - The question has eluded us. He said, "I'm 100 percent focused on my campaign," he said. "I am running for state office, and that is all I am making right now. I just finished primary, and as you said, this hill is going to be very steep this year, and that's all I'm focusing on." In the late 2016 campaign, after the release of the now famous Hollywood tape in which Trump referred to the removal of women's genitals, Jacobs said that Tramp's remarks were "not presidential." In the New York State Code of Policy, Nick Riceman quoted Jacob as saying: "I am terrified and disgusted by these statements made by Mr. Trump. It is unacceptable and certainly not presidential. In 2017, after Trump took office, Jacobs criticized Trump ' s response to the opium abuse crisis, saying that the President should declare a national emergency. Our judgment Collins called Jacobs "Never" Tremper using the passion of the present. While Jacobs avoided questions about whether Trump ' s support during the 2016 elections was occasionally criticized, there was no evidence that it was or was never "trampmer," a name usually given to Republicans and conservatives who declared themselves opposed to Trump ' s candidacy and opposed his campaign again. Jacob says today that he supports Trump and his agenda. We're assessing Collins's false claim.
